item.title: Hello world!
item.dc:creator: legendarysid
item.content:encoded: Welcome to WordPress. This is your first post. Edit or delete it, then start writing!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hi, this is a comment. To delete a comment, just log in and view the post's comments. There you will have the option to edit or delete them.

item.title: Sample Page
item.dc:creator: legendarysid
item.content:encoded:
This is an example page. It's different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:
Hi there! I'm a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my blog. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas. (And gettin' caught in the rain.)
...or something like this:
The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickeys to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.
As a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!

item.title: Heavy snow affects travel in Yorkshire and Lancashire
item.dc:creator: legendarysid
item.content:encoded:
Heavy snowfall has caused "chaos" in parts of northern England, with forecasters predicting further cold weather in the days to come.

Yorkshire and Lancashire have been worst affected, after 2-5cm fell overnight, with 10cm reported on higher ground. Leeds Bradford Airport was forced to suspend all flights this morning, but it has since reopened. More than 100 schools have been closed across East Lancashire and Oldham. Parts of Staffordshire have also been affected, with several centimetres of snow reported in Flash, England's highest village. Commuters have been urged to allow extra journey time, and the Met Office has issued snow and ice warnings. "Looks like Narnia" [caption id="attachment_26" align="aligncenter" width="624"] Heavy snow fell in Saddleworth, near Oldham[/caption] Molly Greenwood reported 10cm of snow in the Huddersfield area. "Don't think I'm going anywhere," she said. Zulfi Hussain said the snow was causing "traffic chaos" on Woodhall Road, Calverley, near Leeds. Elliott Hudson, another West Yorkshire resident, said: "Looks like I have woken up in Narnia." A warning of snow and ice is in place for North Yorkshire, South Yorkshire and West Yorkshire. The A628 Woodhead, A57 Snake Pass and A537 Cat and Fiddle roads are all affected, with delays reported on the M65 motorway. Highways England said the A57 eastbound in Great Manchester is closed between M67/A560 and B6174 due to severe weather conditions. It said specialist teams are working to clear the road.

item.title: Oculus Rift will be on Macs when Apple releases 'a good computer'
item.dc:creator: legendarysid
item.content:encoded: The founder of Oculus Rift has dented any hope of Mac owners being able to use the virtual reality company’s Rift headset in the near future, saying he will only release an Apple-compatible version “if they ever release a good computer”. Palmer Luckey, whose virtual reality headset was bought by Facebook for $2bn (£1.4bn), said even the most powerful Mac computers were incapable of supporting the Rift, and that the company doesn’t prioritise high-end computing. “It just boils down to the fact that Apple doesn’t prioritise high-end GPUs. You can buy a $6,000 Mac Pro with the top-of-the-line AMD FirePro D700s, and it still doesn’t match our recommended spec," he told Shack News. "If they prioritised higher-end GPUs like they used to for a while back in the day, we’d love to support Mac, but right now there’s just not a single machine out there that supports it, so even if we could support it on the software side, there’s just no audience of people who could run the vast majority of software out there.” Less than one per cent of the world’s computers - some 13 million machines - are capable of running the sophisticated software required for VR, according to graphics chip maker Nvidia. Powerful graphics cards such as the Nvidia GeForce 970 or AMD Radeon 290 are needed to display images on the headsets clearly at around 90 frames per second, when standard laptops run at around 30 frames per second. A common problem which plagues VR headsets is latency - the delay between moving your head and the pixels re-assembling themselves on the screen, which can cause discord between your motion-detecting inner ear and what your eyes see, causing nausea. The lower the frame rate, the higher the chances you will experience nausea. When asked how he felt about competition from HTC’s Vive and PlayStation VR, Luckey said if Oculus was the sole player within the industry, “that would probably be a scary indicator”. “It would mean that other people didn’t see what we’re seeing, and the fact that there are other people jumping into the VR space shows that VR is something people believe in - once they try it, they believe in it,” he said. “There’s a lot of people from companies from teeny-tiny one man teams, all the way up to big multi-hundred billion dollar corporations believe that VR is going to be the next major computing platform.” Rift headsets will start shipping to consumers this month, in the wake of fan dissatisfaction at the US price of $599 (UK pricing is £499). In a Reddit AMA session 23 year-old Luckey said he was frustrated at previous media reports the Rift would cost in the region of $1,500, when in reality that cost encompasses the cost of the system and a computer powerful enough to run it. "Later on, I tried to get across that Rift would cost more than many expected, in the past two weeks particularly," he said. "There are a lot of reasons we did not do a better job of prepping people who already have high end GPUs, legal, financial, competitive, and otherwise, but to be perfectly honest, our biggest failing was assuming we had been clear enough about setting expectations." He later took to Twitter, saying: "High end VR is expensive, but Rift is obscenely cheap for what it is". “It costs a lot of money to make a really high-end VR headset, and for those $600 you’re getting a lot more than you get spending it on a phone or on a TV,” he added. “When you buy a phone for $600, you’re not getting really as much stuff for that $600.” Luckey added that the company had been working on original content for years, but refused to be drawn on which was his favourite.
